fields.description:
Benthic invertebrates

a generalized biomass of consumers that live on the seafloor and derive their energy from organic matter than sinks to the seafloor. This group has no explicit size.

Demersal fish

also referred to as groundfish, this functional group represents fish that live near the seafloor and are generalist predators that feed on both fish and benthic invertebrates. In the California Current System, example species included in this group would be Canary Rockfish, Dover Sole, Pacific Cod, and Sablefish.

Forage fish

– also referred to as small pelagics, this functional group represents planktivorous fish that inhabit the epipelagic and serve as prey for higher trophic levels. In the California Current System, example species included in this group would be Pacific sardine, Pacific mackerel, jack mackerel, and northern anchovy. Though this functional type uses fish physiology, it fills a similar ecological niche as market squid and krill, thus it may represent some of their dynamics.

Large Fish

the largest size class that spans 0.25–125 kg (0.29–2.32 m) and includes the adult demersal and large pelagic functional types. Large sizes of the large pelagic fish are found in the epipelagic, while the habitat of large demersal fish depends on the seafloor depth. In waters over the continental shelf (<200 m) large demersal use the whole water column, but are restricted to the seafloor at deeper depths.

Medium Fish

the intermediate size class that spans 0.5–250 g (36.8–292.4 mm) and includes both adult forage fish and late juvenile stages of the demersal and large pelagic functional types. Medium size classes of the forage fish and large pelagic fish inhabit the epipelagic, while the medium size class of demersal fish are near the seafloor. Prey depends on the functional type.

Pelagic fish

– also referred to as highly migratory species (though migration is not simulated in FEISTY), this functional group represents piscivorous fish that inhabit the epipelagic and act as top predators. In the California Current System, example species included in this group would be North Pacific albacore, swordfish, striped marlin, and yellowfin tuna.

Small Fish

the smallest size class that spans 1–500 mg (4.6–36.8 mm) and represents larval and early juvenile stages of all three fish functional types (forage, demersal, large pelagic). Assumed to feed on mesozooplankton only and be exclusively epipelagic.

Fish

are aquatic, craniate, gill-bearing animals that lack limbs with digits. Included in this definition are the living hagfish, lampreys, and cartilaginous and bony fish as well as various extinct related groups. Around 99% of living fish species are ray-finned fish, belonging to the class Actinopterygii, with over 95% belonging to the teleost subgrouping.


The earliest organisms that can be classified as fish were soft-bodied chordates that first appeared during the Cambrian period. Although they lacked a true spine, they possessed notochords which allowed them to be more agile than their invertebrate counterparts. Fish would continue to evolve through the Paleozoic era, diversifying into a wide variety of forms. Many fish of the Paleozoic developed external armor that protected them from predators. The first fish with jaws appeared in the Silurian period, after which many (such as sharks) became formidable marine predators rather than just the prey of arthropods.
